awd_titl_txt: Cornell Center for Materials Research - MRSEC
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: The Cornell Center for Materials Research (CCMR), a Materials Research Science and Engineering Center, is enhancing national capabilities in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics fields and materials research at all levels through an integrated research and education program. The central mission of the Center is to explore and advance the design, control, and fundamental understanding of materials through collaborative experimental and theoretical studies. The Center focuses on forefront scientific challenges of a scope and complexity requiring the combined expertise of interdisciplinary teams of researchers and collaborators. In doing so, the Center is developing the underlying science needed, for example, to advance next-generation computer memories, to enable information processing with light, and to realize a new class of self-folding devices based on atomically-thin, paper-like materials. Through these research activities, the Center is educating a diverse cadre of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars to become leaders in the field of materials research at industrial, academic, and government organizations, while also developing pedagogical materials for K-12 classrooms that excite and inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers. The CCMR Shared Facilities enable frontier research while enhancing the nation's infrastructure for advanced research and development.

Technical Abstract: The goal of the Mechanisms, Materials, and Devices for Spin Manipulation IRG is to discover, understand, and apply new mechanisms for controlling spins in magnetic devices. The Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRG's) research aims to provide the scientific foundations for energy-efficient nonvolatile memories with revolutionary capabilities as well as frequency-agile nanoscale microwave sources and signal-processing devices. The goal of the Structured Materials for Strong Light-Matter Interactions IRG is to understand, create, and harness exceptionally strong and unconventional light-matter interactions for scientific discoveries and future photonic information processing technology. The IRG aims to enhance the nonlinear effects that enable photon-photon and photon-matter interactions and to efficiently create and control the emission of high-quality single photons for quantum optical technology. The IRG is designing, fabricating, and testing "structured materials:"  high-performance optical materials that are sculpted on the nano- or mesoscale to enhance their optical properties, enabling stronger photon-photon and photon-material interactions. The goal of the 2D Atomic Membranes for 3D Systems IRG is to explore the fundamental challenges associated with transducing small local signals into global observable changes at nanoscale dimensions in a targeted design structure. To do this, the group is combining recent advances in two-dimensional atomic membranes growth with the scale-invariant properties of the centuries-old art forms of origami ("ori" = fold) and kirigami ("kiri" = cut). Their aim is to take miniaturization to its ultimate limit, creating atomically thin "paper" materials that self-fold into incredibly responsive structures with lateral features at the micron to nanometer scale. Through a series of integrated educational activities, the CCMR is impacting K-12 teachers and students; undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral scholars; and faculty.

por.por_cntn:
The central mission of the Cornell Center for Materials Research was to develop mastery of materials at the nanoscale, through collaborative experimental and theoretical studies. The Center enabled technological progress by exploring fundamental materials research challenges with scope and complexity that required sustained contributions of interdisciplinary research groups (IRGs). The Center’s mission also included educational activities for students from kindergarten through 12th grade, industrial outreach and knowledge transfer, and the operation of shared research facilities available to the broader research community.

Intellectual Merit

The Mechanisms, Materials, and Devices for Spin Manipulation IRG has advanced understanding of electron spins in nanoscale magnetic materials, along with mechanisms to achieve the electrical control of these spins. In addition to revealing a wide range of fundamental materials physics, this research will underpin new nonvolatile magnetic memory technologies that are much smaller, more energy-efficient, faster, and less-expensive than other technologies. The work of this IRG can also lead to nanometer-scale sources of microwave fields, which will be useful as sensitive magnetic-field sensors. 

The goal of the Structured Materials for Strong Light-Matter Interactions IRG was to understand, create, and harness exceptionally-strong light-matter interactions for scientific discoveries and future optical information technologies.  The group developed new “structured materials” consisting of thin layers and structures of those layers that are designed to provide unique optical properties, which are then exploited to control light-matter interactions at the nanoscale. Results include development of the underlying materials and physics of single-photon emitters that are necessary for quantum information-processing systems, development of materials and structure designs necessary to enhance light-matter interactions that are nonlinear (that depend on the intensity of the light), and combining theory and experimental methods to establish new nonlinear-optical mechanisms.

The central aim of the 2D Nanomaterials for Active 3D Metamaterials and Microsystems IRG was to create atomically-thin 2D “paper” materials that, in response to their environment,  bend or fold into 3D structures with lateral features ranging from the nanometer-scale to the micrometer-scale.  This IRG performed the basic materials growth, characterization, and design to make this revolution possible. The 3D structures could ultimately be used for devices with novel physical, optical, electrical, and/or chemical functionalities, including micro-robots. 

The work of Center researchers was documented in 1,587 publications in scientific journals.  Of these, 338 publications were supported primarily by the Center’s NSF funds, and 106 publications appeared in high-profile journals.

Broader Impacts

During the period of support, 107 graduate students who participated in Center projects received the PhD degree.  Of these, 27% are women and 10.3% are underrepresented minorities.  In addition, 41 postdoctoral associates completed their appointments, of which 19.5% are women, and 2.4% are underrepresented minorities.

The Center promoted undergraduate summer research experiences and mentorship. In conjunction with a separate award for the summer undergraduate program, the Center hosted 106 students between 2018 and 2024. Of these, 33% are from under-represented minority groups, 54% are female, and 41% came from institutions that are not research-intensive. The Center’s Educational Outreach program hosted an array of educational outreach programs that targeted students and teachers between kindergarten and 12th grade, with a focus on schools in New York City, Syracuse, Washington D.C., and Puerto Rico. To support teachers in meeting Next Generation Science Standards and to put science in the hands of students, the CCMR Lending Library of Experiments developed over 40 modules that helped young students understand topics in physics, chemistry, and earth science. These kits could be requested on the CCMR website and were available at no cost to any teacher/school in the United States.  The kits reached over 4,000 students each year nationwide.
